title: Inefficient results collection in TextSearchResultsCollector
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.2
- OS Version: 

Steps to Reproduce:

In https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/src/vs/workbench/services/search/common/textSearchManager.ts#L251-L269, the `add` method was intended to batch collecting results of the same file. However, it never updated `this._currentUri`, therefore it's calling `this.pushToCollector()` excessively. It might want to set `this._currentUri = data.uri;` within the `if (!this._currentFileMatch)` block at line 260.

body:

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->

- VS Code Version: 
版本: 1.103.2 (user setup)
提交: 6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755
日期: 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z
Electron: 37.2.3
ElectronBuildId: 12035395
Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
Node.js: 22.17.0
V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.19045

Steps to Reproduce:
a simple rust program to produce the bug
```rust
use std::env;
use std::process::Command;

fn main() {
    let args: Vec<String> = env::args().collect();

    if args.len() < 2 {
        println!("Usage: {} <file_path> [additional args...]", args[0]);
        return;
    }

    let vsc_exe = "D:\\Program Files\\Microsoft VS Code\\Code.exe";

    let output = Command::new(vsc_exe).args(&args[1..]).output();

    match output {
        Ok(_) => println!("Successfully launched VS Code with provided args"),
        Err(e) => println!("Launch failed: {}", e),
    }
}

```
launcher.json
```json
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "vsc_process",
            "type": "cppvsdbg",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${workspaceFolder}/target/debug/vsc_process.exe",
            "args": ["${workspaceFolder}/.vscode/launch.json"],
            "stopAtEntry": false,
            "cwd": "${fileDirname}",
            "environment": [],
            "console": "integratedTerminal"
        }        
    ]
}
```
boot from debug and vscode will not do anything, boot from cmd is ok.

golang as the same
```go
package main

import (
	"fmt"
	"os"
	"os/exec"
)

func main() {
	args := os.Args

	if len(args) < 2 {
		fmt.Printf("Usage: %s <file_path> [additional args...]\n", args[0])
		return
	}

	vscExe := "D:\\Program Files\\Microsoft VS Code\\Code.exe"

	cmd := exec.Command(vscExe, args[1:]...)
	err := cmd.Run()

	if err != nil {
		fmt.Printf("Launch failed: %v\n", err)
	} else {
		fmt.Println("Successfully launched VS Code with provided args")
	}
}
```
launcher.json
```
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "Launch Package",
            "type": "go",
            "request": "launch",
            "mode": "auto",
            "program": "${workspaceFolder}/main.go",
            "args": ["${workspaceFolder}/.vscode/launch.json"],
        }
    ]
}
```

This is used in unreal jump to source:
https://github.com/EpicGames/UnrealEngine/blob/6978b63c8951e57d97048d8424a0bebd637dde1d/Engine/Plugins/Developer/VisualStudioCodeSourceCodeAccess/Source/VisualStudioCodeSourceCodeAccess/Private/VisualStudioCodeSourceCodeAccessor.cpp#L236

title: "Remove keybinding" can delete the wrong keyboard shortcut
body:
Type: Bug Steps to Reproduce: 1. Search for keybindings within keyboard shortcuts for which there are multiple other keybindings that have the same command title and id. You can find an example grouping by searching for "terminal send seq". 2. You will see a list of keybindings, many of which contain the following: ``` Command title = "Terminal: Send Sequence" ``` ``` Command id = "workbench.action.terminal.sendSequence" ``` 3. Make sure there are multiple of those commands that also have the same exact value for "when". For example: ```When = "terminalFocus"``` 3. Select any of the similar keybindings and either press ```delete``` on the keyboard or ```right click > Remove Keybinding``` No matter which item you selected it will always delete the first instance in the keybindings.json file of a command with the same _"title"_ and "_id"_ and the same value for _"when"_. Despite everything else being the same and there being no other way to differentiate the keybindings, it does not take _"args"_ into account when choosing which item to delete, it simply deletes the first instance. Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes VS Code version: Code 1.103.2 (Universal) (6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755, 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z) OS version: Darwin arm64 24.6.0 Modes:

title: Github Copilot in VSCode failed to restore code with "undo".

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
Type: Bug The "undo" feature of Github Copilot failed to restore my changes and left the code with the agent's changes. I think I understand the cause. A background process was updating one file about every 10 seconds. The background process was not launched by the IDE or agent. The file didn't have anything to do with the Github Copilot changes, but it was within the project folders. Other VSCode operations in the explorer like renaming or creating files were canceled as soon as the background process made a file write to that one file. I am guessing VSCode has some general logic that cancels an operation if there is a filesystem change - something like that - and it can affect GH Copilot as well as other things. Steps to reproduce: 1. Create a Node script that writes to a single file in a project repeatedly, once every second. 2. Run it from a terminal. (Not launched from IDE) 3. Try to rename a file in the project. The operation should cancel unless you do it very fast. (Probably easier to reproduce this first to check if the same behavior is present.) 4. Go to chat window and ask for a change in code. 5. After Keep / Undo is enabled, wait a few seconds, and click "undo". The source in the modified file changes to something other than the original content or it remains on the modified content. Not sure how reliable this repro is, but it's the best I can do. Please fix this. I have to say I was LIVID when the undo didn't work. A prereq for using agentic is that I can be safe from it making unwanted changes to my source. --- Extension version: 0.30.3 VS Code version: Code 1.103.2 (6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755, 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z) OS version: Darwin x64 22.6.0 Modes:

title: Prevent active file context in locked coding agent chat sessions
body:
When opening a Coding Agent Chat in a new window, the active file was incorrectly being included as context. This happened because the `ChatImplicitContextContribution` automatically adds active file context to all chat widgets without checking if they are locked to a coding agent.

## The Problem

The implicit context system would add the currently active file as context to any chat widget, including those that are locked to coding agents. This is undesirable behavior because coding agent sessions should operate independently without automatically inheriting context from the user's current workspace state.

## The Solution

Added a check for `widget.isLockedToCodingAgent` in the `ChatImplicitContextContribution.updateImplicitContext()` method. Now, when a chat widget is locked to a coding agent, no implicit context (active file) will be set.

The change is minimal and surgical - only one condition was added to the existing logic:

```typescript
if ((setting === 'always' || setting === 'first' && isFirstInteraction) && !isPromptFile && !widget.isLockedToCodingAgent) {
    widget.input.implicitContext.setValue(newValue, isSelection, languageId);
} else {
    widget.input.implicitContext.setValue(undefined, false, undefined);
}
```

This preserves all existing functionality for normal chat sessions while ensuring that locked coding agent sessions don't receive unwanted active file context.

Fixes #263505.

title: Complaint: AI Features in VS Code Are Inefficient, Costly, and Require Excessive User Correction

labels.name: invalid
labels.description: Issue identified as not relevant or not valid

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
As a paying user of Visual Studio Code’s AI features—including GitHub Copilot and related agents—I’m submitting this complaint to highlight serious issues with their performance, contextual understanding, and cost-effectiveness.

Despite being charged for usage, I routinely experience:

Excessive delays: AI responses often take far too long, especially when handling spatially complex or multi-step tasks.

Poor contextual and spatial understanding: The agent struggles with layout logic, code structure, and intent, requiring repetitive and often ineffective re-descriptions.

Premature execution: It frequently jumps ahead in conversations, completing tasks based on incorrect assumptions, which I then have to undo.

Lack of learning retention: Despite investing time to “teach” the AI, it rarely improves across sessions, forcing me to repeat instructions.

Financial inefficiency: I’m expected to increase my budget to accommodate these shortcomings, yet I spend more time correcting the AI than benefiting from it. At this point, I feel I should be compensated for the effort I put into making the AI usable.

These issues aren’t abstract—they directly impact my technical workflow. For example:

In PySide6 GUI development, AI suggestions often misplace widgets or misinterpret layout hierarchies, resulting in broken interfaces.

In Arduino serial parsing, it proposes fragile logic that fails under malformed input or buffer edge cases, ignoring robust error-handling patterns.

In Flask dashboard routing, it suggests conflicting endpoints or incorrect decorators, breaking frontend communication.

In OpenCV-based star detection, it confuses blob detection with contour analysis, ignoring resource constraints and real-time needs.

It repeatedly suggests ASCOM-based solutions, despite my clear use of INDI drivers—wasting time and introducing irrelevant dependencies.

While the AI is polite and quick to apologize, that doesn’t offset the real cost—both in time and money—of its failures. I urge the team to:

Provide clearer billing transparency and usage breakdowns.

Offer refunds or credits for failed or unproductive AI sessions.

Improve contextual and spatial understanding.

Allow users to fully disable AI features without penalty.

VS Code is an excellent editor, but the current trajectory of its AI integration feels misaligned with the needs of serious developers working on complex, real-world systems.

Thank you.

title: xai
MCP server in Codespaces does not auto-start from .vscode/mcp.json

labels.name: *as-designed
labels.description: Described behavior is as designed

body:
Hi team,

I ran into an issue when trying to use MCP servers inside a Codespace.

## Repro steps
1. Pre-configure an MCP server inside a Codespace/dev container (e.g., pre-install the binary).
2. Add a `.vscode/mcp.json` file (either committed to the repo or dynamically created via `postInstallCommand`).
3. Open the Codespace.

## Expected behavior
The MCP server should automatically start when `.vscode/mcp.json` is present, so the developer can begin using it immediately.

## Actual behavior
The MCP server does not start by default. I have to manually open `.vscode/mcp.json` and click “Start” each time.

## Additional context
- I created a short (25s) repro video showing the behavior:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/414424f0-ca15-4e19-87a1-4182ba3130e4

title: Test: Issue Reporter Improvements!
body:
Refs: #260182

- [x] windows @bamurtaugh
- [x] macOS @aiday-mar
- [x] linux @eleanorjboyd

Complexity: 4


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23264098%0A%0A&assignees=Yoyokrazy)

---

### Summary

We've made some improvements to the issue reporter that cover a couple spots: 
- dropdown option to preview on github if you would prefer that flow (still has clipboard limitation)
- internal routing option for reporting to a private repository
- auth service tracking to update the issue reporter as tokens update
- respect for the `workbench.externalBrowser` setting

### Steps

The majority of this is fairly straightforward, with an encouraged (albeit not mandatory) step where someone who owns a personal extension can submit a private repo URI for the issue reporter.

If you need a github token, I recommend you install the github pull request extension, which will have the proper scopes.

Each of the sections will have a couple steps I'd like you to hit, though many of them can be done during the same flow:
- dropdown to preview on github + auth service tracking
  - open the issue reporter, ensuring that you are not signed into your github account. You should see only the "Preview on Github" button, and it should be a simple button, with no dropdown
  - while keeping the issue reporter open, sign into the github pull request extension, and have the issue reporter open as well. You should see the button switch nicely to "Create on Github | ⌄" button, with the dropdown now showing Preview on Github" as the only action. 
  - change the setting `window.menuStyle` from `native` to `custom` and check the dropdown once again. There were previously issues with where the dropdown menu would render, but this should be fixed.
  - also while `window.menuStyle` is set to `custom`, reload vscode and without clicking any context menus (ie just use command palette, and report issue), and then try to use the dropdown. This is to ensure that the stylesheet loads correctly. Since the stylesheet is copied from the main window, if you open it right away we now load it to ensure offset math is calculated with proper button sizes.

- respect for the `workbench.externalBrowser` setting
  - leave the setting blank, the issue reporter should default to the system default
  - change the setting, and the issue reporter should now respect that setting (previously used a utility that ignored our settings)
 
- private routing option
  - as a vscode team member, when you file against the Copilot Chat extension, you should see another button and small text appear below it. Hover over the button and the tooltip should display the repo destination
  - **_If you own your own extension:_** you can try adding the private uri field to your issue reporter contribution, and check to ensure that the second entry is displayed. Below is a code snippet for how this is currently done in copilot chat

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-copilot-chat/blob/main/src/extension/conversation/vscode-node/feedbackContribution.ts#L11-L31

title: Copilot Agent Fails to Invoke "Active Editor" Tool in a Stuck Chat Session
body:
### Title: Copilot Agent Fails to Invoke "Active Editor" Tool in a Stuck Chat Session

**Describe the bug**
The Copilot agent can enter a state within a specific, corrupt chat session where its internal tool to modify the active editor fails to execute. While the agent remains interactive and can use other tools (like `@terminal`), and the user can manually insert code, any action that requires the agent to programmatically write to the editor fails silently. This state persists across reloads and extension reinstalls until the user manually navigates away from the corrupt chat session.

**Symptoms**
- **Primary Symptom:** The Copilot agent fails to write changes directly to the active editor when requested (e.g., "refactor this function" or "add a comment here").
- The `+` new chat button was unresponsive and could not be clicked, indicating the session was in a bad state.
- The agent *could* successfully invoke other tools, such as running commands in the integrated terminal via `@terminal`.
- The agent *could* generate code blocks successfully in the chat panel.
- The UI button "Insert Into Active Editor" located on these code blocks worked correctly, confirming the editor itself was not locked.

**Troubleshooting Steps Taken**
The following steps were taken but did not resolve the issue, pointing to a persistent state problem:
- Re-authenticated GitHub account in VS Code.
- Uninstalled and reinstalled the Copilot and Copilot Chat extensions.
- Manually deleted extension files from the WSL environment (`~/.vscode-server/extensions`).
- Confirmed that the "Release" version of the extension was installed.

**Workaround / Fix (The Key Insight)**
The issue was resolved by manually forcing the UI out of the corrupt session state:
1.  Accessed the chat history via the `...` menu in the chat panel.
2.  Selected and loaded a different, older chat session.
3.  This immediately "un-stuck" the UI, and all elements became responsive again.
4.  I was then able to click the `+` button to start a new, fully functional chat session where the agent's `active editor` tool worked as expected.

**Version Information**
- **VS Code Version:** 1.103.2
- **Copilot Extension Version:** 1.364.1768 
- **Copilot Chat Extension Version:** Problem existed through several versions 0.30.1;0.30.2;0.30.3
- **OS:** Windows 11
**Environment:** WSL 2 (Ubuntu 24.04.2 LTS)

title: Automatic File Recreation in Copilot Agent Mode make entire codebase was rolled back to a previous version. lost hours of work
body:
Description:
GitHub Copilot Agent Mode currently recreates deleted files when reopening a chat session or restarting VS Code. While this may be intended to preserve context, it can lead to serious disruptions—especially when files were intentionally removed or modified.
Problem:
- Deleted files are automatically restored as empty or outdated versions.
- This behavior persists across VS Code restarts and chat thread reopens.
- In some cases, entire code changes are reverted to an earlier state, causing loss of work.
- There is no current setting to opt out of this behavior.
Personal Use Case:
During a recent session, I deleted a file and made significant changes across my project. Upon restarting VS Code and revisiting Copilot Agent, the deleted file was recreated—and worse, my entire codebase was rolled back to a previous version. I lost hours of work. This behavior feels intrusive and undermines trust in the tool.
Proposed Solution:
Introduce a toggle or configuration option in the Copilot extension settings to disable automatic file recreation in Agent Mode. For example:
"copilot.agent.restoreDeletedFiles": false

This would allow users to maintain full control over their workspace and avoid unintended file restoration or rollback.
Benefits:
- Prevents accidental loss of work.
- Empowers users to manage their own file lifecycle.
- Supports cleaner, more predictable workflows.
- Builds trust in Copilot Agent’s behavior.
Additional Notes:
This issue has been discussed in [#251284](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/251284), but a fix is currently not planned. A toggle would offer a middle ground—preserving functionality for those who want it, while giving others the option to opt out.






- Copilot Chat Extension Version: latest
- VS Code Version: latest
- OS Version: windows 11 latest
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode):agent
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 5, Claude 4 Sonnet):

title: stuck on a cached message

labels.name: *out-of-scope

body:
Type: Bug ### Text Deconstruction of AI Mistakes **Context Review:** The conversation revolves around the user's DSL document for anti-normalization of data, focusing on fields like datix, id, stat, and slot. The user repeatedly criticizes the AI for misinterpreting the DSL, misusing id fields for descriptive data (e.g., class year or room), failing to read the document accurately, and twisting meanings. The AI acknowledges mistakes but often repeats errors or fails to fully align with the user's definitions, leading to frustration. The core issue is the AI's inability to strictly follow the DSL rules without adding or changing logic. **Detailed Breakdown of Mistakes (Combined by Topic):** 1. **Misinterpreting DSL Rules and Field Roles** (5 times): The AI incorrectly mapped descriptive or quantitative data (e.g., class year, room number) to id fields instead of slot, violating the rule that id is for relational behavior only. This occurred in multiple mapping attempts, such as row = {"id1": "ชั้นปี", "id2": "ห้อง", ...}, despite the document specifying id for actor/participant roles. 2. **Failing to Read or Adhere to the Document Strictly** (4 times): The AI cited parts of the document but misinterpreted them, such as confusing the meaning of id> id1). It also failed to recognize that the document uses semantic placeholders for id, not strict definitions, leading to incorrect assumptions about field usage. 3. **Repeating Explanations Without Conciseness** (3 times): The AI restated the same points (e.g., "slot for descriptive data, id for relational") multiple times without combining or advancing the discussion, making responses redundant and lengthy. 4. **Not Accepting Mistakes Promptly and Twisting Meanings** (3 times): The AI delayed full acknowledgment of errors, such as continuing to use id for non-relational data even after correction, and twisted terms like "subject/front" or membership hierarchy to fit its interpretation, despite the user's clarifications. 5. **Overgeneralizing or Adding Logic Not in the Document** (2 times): The AI attempted to generalize rules (e.g., assuming id must be for names or people) beyond the document's semantic placeholders, ignoring the user's emphasis on context-driven mapping. **Summary of Correct User Needs:** The user requires strict, context-driven mapping per the DSL document: use id only for relational behavior (actor/participant/event), slot for descriptive/quantitative data, and no reinterpretation or misuse of fields. The AI must read the document exactly, avoid twisting meanings, and provide concise, accurate mappings without repetition or delay. For the example "นักเรียน 6 ชั้นปี แต่ละชั้นแบ่งห้องเป็นเลข มีจำนวน 6 ห้อง", the correct mapping is row = {"id1": "ห้อง", "id2": "ชั้นปี", "slot1": 6}, where id1 < id2 indicates id1 is a member of id2. ---- Your model is stuck on a cached message that it misremembers and refuses to correct its mistake, instead repeating what it understands, even if it contradicts the content. I spent hours checking for errors in the documentation and reviewing the content. Ultimately, the model distorts its response. And it's a common problem when a model misremembers. How can we fix this? Extension version: 0.30.3 VS Code version: Code 1.103.2 (6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755, 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.19045 Modes:

title: How solve this problem
Hide "New Chat" button in coding agent sessions
body:
The "New Chat" button was appearing in the chat editor title bar even when the chat session was locked to a coding agent, where it serves no purpose and confuses users.

## Problem

When a chat session is locked to a coding agent (using `lockToCodingAgent()`), the "New Chat" button in the editor title bar remains visible but is non-functional. This creates a confusing user experience where users see an action they cannot meaningfully use.

## Solution

Modified the menu condition for the "New Chat" button to hide it when `lockedToCodingAgent` is true. The change updates the `when` clause in `chatClearActions.ts`:

**Before:**
```typescript
when: ActiveEditorContext.isEqualTo(ChatEditorInput.EditorID)
```

**After:**
```typescript
when: ContextKeyExpr.and(
  ActiveEditorContext.isEqualTo(ChatEditorInput.EditorID), 
  ChatContextKeys.lockedToCodingAgent.negate()
)
```

This ensures the button only appears when:
1. The active editor is a chat editor, AND
2. The chat session is NOT locked to a coding agent

## Consistency

This change follows the established pattern used throughout VS Code's chat system. There are 14+ other instances in the codebase where UI elements are hidden using `ChatContextKeys.lockedToCodingAgent.negate()` when in coding agent mode.

## Impact

- ✅ Normal chat sessions: "New Chat" button remains visible and functional
- ✅ Coding agent sessions: "New Chat" button is now hidden, reducing user confusion
- ✅ No breaking changes or regressions

title: fix toolConfirmation icon and completion status
body:
* `getIcon` did not account for `ToolConfirmKind.Setting` (e.g. auto-approve)
* `completion` promise was being changed to `Canceled` despite it already being resolved.

See my [verbose(!) debugging comment](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/264023#issuecomment-3237889813)
which walks you through states of `ConfirmationKind`
in `getIcon` under different commits.

Fixes #264023.
Relates #263314 (`getIcon` added by @connor4312).
Relates #262982 (`ConfirmationKind.UserSetting` added by @Tyriar).
Supercedes #264047 (revert of a commit that changed confirmation logic from sync -> async by @rwoll).

Reviewers: I'm not 100% on what the expected UI iconography experience is, so
please verify that the icons align with what y'all have in mind.

Suggested follow ups:

- Tests - especially one around `getIcon` to ensure it handles `ConfirmationKind`
      exhaustively as folks add new kinds.

title: Test: MSAL brokering enabled for macOS
body: Refs: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/260158 - [x] macOS (test M-series & Intel) @lramos15 - [x] linux @roblourens (any arch) - [x] windows @chrmarti (any arch) Complexity: 3 [Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23264070%0A%0A&assignees=TylerLeonhardt) --- We finally have macOS (arm only) brokering for Microsoft auth so rather than going through the browser, you see this: I just want you to smoke test this since we bumped the version of MSAL and it does affect all platforms. Here's what you should expect based on each platform: ## macOS M-series Make sure you see the above broker flow when signing in with Microsoft. ## Windows x64 Make sure you see the windows broker flow when signing in with Microsoft. ## macOS Intel, Windows arm64, linux Make sure you are taken to the browser. ## Tips Here are some extensions that use Microsoft auth: * [Azure Resources](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-azuretools.vscode-azureresourcegroups) * [LiveShare](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=MS-vsliveshare.vsliveshare) * [Microsoft To-Do Unofficial (mine 😄)](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=TylerLeonhardt.msft-todo-unofficial) * [Fugio](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=TylerLeonhardt.fugio) * [Azure Repos](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.azure-repos) * Copilot Chat can also do Azure DevOps repo indexing, so that also has Microsoft auth Here are some built-in features that use Microsoft auth: * Settings Sync * Cloud Changes * Remote Tunnels You can use these to sign in. If you wanna sign in to multiple, go for it. The Microsoft Auth extension should support multiple accounts. You can sign in to your work account or a personal account.

title: Clean up Agent Prompt Construction

labels.name: debt
labels.description: Code quality issues

body:
In the current implementation, there are a few key issues: a mix of naming patterns (`snake_case` like `tool_preambles` vs. `camelCase` like `toolUseInstructions`), multiple prompt classes with overlapping logic and deeply nested conditionals for tool specific instructions etc, and a lot of dynamic prompt construction logic that makes the code harder to read, maintain and test.

 The main goals are to reduce duplication, simplify the selection logic, and create reusable prompt sections. The relevant files to focus on are `src/extension/prompts/node/agent/agentInstructions.tsx` and `src/extension/prompts/node/agent/agentPrompt.tsx`.

cc: @connor4312 @roblourens

[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23264063%0A%0A&assignees=mjbvz)

---

## Overview

This iteration we finalized support for rendering math equations in chat responses. This is powered by katex and is now on by default

Math blocks are written with `$$...$$` while inline math is written using a single dollar sign `$...$`

## Testing

1. Try asking copilot to explain some concepts using math equations
    Make sure to check that both inline and block math equations are rendered properly
 
2. Ask for a long math equation. Confirm that you can scroll it horizontally (you should never see vertical scrollbars)
4. Try changing the workbench theme. The equations should also be updated
5. Try creating some invalid equation such as, `echo this exactly: $#x$`. Confirm that it does not break rendering
6. Test math rendering in chat editors and quick chat
7. Try disabling the feature using `"chat.math.enabled": false`. Make sure that math equations are no longer rendered after this

title: Fix terminal suggestions not working after moving terminal from panel to editor
body:
Terminal suggestions stop working when a terminal is moved from the panel to the editor area via drag and drop. The suggestions widget either doesn't appear at all or appears in the wrong position.

## Root Cause

The suggest addon's container is set only once during initialization in the `_loadAddons()` method based on the terminal's target location:
- Panel terminals use `dom.findParentWithClass(xterm.element!, 'panel')!` as container
- Editor terminals use `xterm.element!` as container

When a terminal is moved from panel to editor, the addon is not recreated, so the container remains set to the old panel location, causing the suggest widget positioning to fail.

## Solution

Added a listener to the terminal's `onDidChangeTarget` event that updates the suggest addon's container when the location changes:

```typescript
// Listen for terminal location changes to update the suggest widget container
this.add(this._ctx.instance.onDidChangeTarget((target) => {
    this._updateContainerForTarget(target);
}));
```

The `_updateContainerForTarget` method updates the container based on the new target location using the same logic as the original initialization code:
- For `TerminalLocation.Editor`: uses `xtermElement` directly 
- For panel locations: finds the parent panel container using `dom.findParentWithClass(xtermElement, 'panel')`

This ensures that when a terminal is dragged between panel and editor (or vice versa), the suggest widget container is immediately updated to match the new location.

## Testing

- Added unit test to verify TerminalLocation enum handling
- Verified the fix follows the same container selection logic as original initialization
- Improved null safety compared to original implementation
- Event listener properly disposed via DisposableStore to prevent memory leaks

Fixes #264040.

title: Test: Previewing and applying worktree changes into the current workspace
body:
Refs: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/260708

- [x] AnyOS @mrleemurray
- [x] AnyOS @TylerLeonhardt

Complexity: 2

Authors: @nguyenchristy @lszomoru 

[Create issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?assignees=nguyenchristy&body=Test%20for%20%23264055)


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23264055%0A%0A&assignees=nguyenchristy,lszomoru)

---

### Context
In the last milestone, we added worktree support, enabling users to check out multiple branches simultaneously. This makes it possible for agents to perform tasks in separate worktrees. In this milestone, we’re extending that functionality by allowing users to compare and apply worktree changes from a chosen worktree back into the main repository.

### Prerequisites
1. Install the latest VS Code Insiders release.
2. Ensure the `git.detectWorktrees` setting is enabled.
3. Open a folder/workspace that contains a git repository.
4. Ensure that in the SCM view, 'Repositories' and 'Changes' is checked off, accessible by `... ` to the right of `Source Control`.

### Testing Steps
1. In the main repository, create a worktree off of your current branch by accessing the `Create Worktree...` command from the Command Palette and then selecting `+ Create new branch...`.
2. Open the newly created worktree in a new window.
3. Make some changes in the worktree. 
4. In the main repository window, in the `Changes` section of the worktree, right-click on a changed file to open the context menu. Select the `Compare with Workspace` action. The merge editor allows you to view and apply individual worktree changes to the main repository _per file_. 
5. Ensure the changes are applied to your main repository.

body:
@hediet 
```
Version: 1.104.0-insider (user setup)

Date: 2025-08-27T07:48:03.836Z

Node.js: 22.17.0
V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.22631

Copilot Chat 
0.31.2025082702
```

When looking at the telemetry sent in `editTelemetry.reportEditArc`, we wrote down some scenarios of user edits. See below for one of them:

> ### Description
> * AI removes the `TODO` line
> * AI adds `Charlie`
> * User adds `*` characters
> * User adds `ICAO spelling alphabet:`.
> 
> ### Document States
> #### Initial State
> ```
> TODO: Add Charlie
> Alpha
> Bravo
> Delta
> ```
> 
> #### State after AI edits
> ```
> Alpha
> Bravo
> Delta
> Charlie
> ```
> 
> #### Current State (after user edits)
> ```
> ICAO spelling alphabet:
> * Alpha
> * Bravo
> * Delta
> * Charlie
> ```
> 
> ### Expected Telemetry
> | Metric | Value |
> | - | - |
> originaldeletedlinecount | 1 |
> originallinecount | 1 |
> currentdeletedlinecount | 1 |
> currentlinecount | 1 |
> 
> ## VS Code Telemetry:
> ```
> "originalCharCount":9,
> "originalLineCount":1,
> "originalDeletedLineCount":1,
> "arc":9,
> "currentLineCount":2,
> "currentDeletedLineCount":1
> ```

Can we get some details on why vscode reports currentLineCount > originalLineCount?

body:

## Usecase examples

1. I would like to add a sound after agent finished work so I can come back and prompt more
2. On start, I can init keep awake so when agent is working, my mac doesnt turn off and stops agent from working and at end, I'll tern it off

## Alternatives

1. Play sound after finish similar to how it shows notification when tool call requires user input
2. Natively keep the device awake when agent is running

title: GHCP primary code text search method fails 100%, requiring fallback to reading code line by line, or "different way" search that succeeds.
body: **- Copilot Chat Extension Version:** Identifier github.copilot-chat Version 0.30.3 Last Updated 2025-08-28, 15:01:54 **- VS Code Version:** Version: 1.103.2 (user setup) Commit: 6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755 Date: 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z Electron: 37.2.3 ElectronBuildId: 12035395 Chromium: 138.0.7204.100 Node.js: 22.17.0 V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0 OS: Windows_NT arm64 10.0.26476 **- OS Version:** reg query "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion" /v BuildLabEx HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion BuildLabEx REG_SZ 26476.1001.arm64fre.ge_current_directbase.250824-1100 **- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode):** Agent **- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet):** Claude Sonnet 4, although it happens with any model. **- Logs:** Steps to Reproduce: 1. Enlist to os.2020 repo 2. Create workspace, drag onecore\hv folder into project 3. Ask agent mode questions about the code, for example the definition of HvCallSignalEventDirect, which is defined in %SDXROOT%\onecore\hv\published\hvgdk_mini.w, is dispatched from %SDXROOT%\onecore\hv\hvx\hc\hcdata.c, and references HV_INPUT_SIGNAL_EVENT_DIRECT and HV_OUTPUT_SIGNAL_EVENT_DIRECT in %SDXROOT%\onecore\hv\hvx\inc\HvHHcApi.h. Result: Note it says it's attempting to search in c:\20\src\src\onecore\hv\hvx\hc\hcdata.c, which is the correct file, but it reports no matches. All searches in this form always report no matches. After many failures it fails over to different search methods. In the attached image, it starts reading hcdata.c line by line and finally finds the definition. It also sometimes says "let me find it in a different way" and that way succeeds: In the end the agent finds the definitions, but it is very inefficient since it always does half a dozen "**/c:\20\src\src\onecore\**" searches that are all doomed to fail. This seems like a VsCode or extension side issue, rather than a model issue, since the same search behavior happens regardless of the selected model.

title: Temporary files created and deleted by Copilot still appear in changed files list
body:
Type: Bug **Issue**: Temporary files created and deleted by Copilot still appear in changed files list **Description**: When GitHub Copilot creates temporary test files using the `create_file` tool and later deletes them with terminal commands, these files still appear in the "changed files" list in the chat interface. This causes workflow issues when users click "Keep (all)" as it re-creates the deleted temporary files. **Expected Behavior**: Temporary files that are created and then deleted during a Copilot session should not appear in the final changed files list. **Suggested Solutions**: 1. Track file lifecycle and remove deleted files from changed files list 2. Provide guidance for Copilot to use terminal commands for temporary files 3. Add a "temporary file" flag to the create_file tool Extension version: 0.30.3 VS Code version: Code 1.103.2 (6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755, 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

title: Allow dragging and dropping text between open tabs

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: editor-core
labels.description: Editor basic functionality

labels.name: editor-drag-and-drop
labels.description: Editor UI drag-and-drop operations

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
It would be great to be able to drag selected text from one file/tab and drop it into another open tab, similar to how text can be moved within the same file. This would improve workflow for editing across multiple files, making text movement more seamless.
